content.raw:
I liked inline initializers after I learned about them when possible because they are more compact and they keep the default value next to the documentation.

I didn't know this before, but [according to cppreference.com](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/initializer_list#Initialization_order) the order of the initializer list doesn't affect the initialization order of non-static data members. Rather, "non-static data members are initialized in order of declaration in the class definition". It may be less convenient, but it seems safer to me to refer to the class definition to know the order of initialization if that is the main concern about "set and forget".
